abstract: Indian J Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg Indian J Otolaryngol Head Neck Surg 1415 ijoto Indian Journal of Otolaryngology and Head & Neck Surgery 2231-3796 0973-7707 Springer PMC11456067 PMC11456067.1 11456067 11456067 39376399 10.1007/s12070-024-04818-1 4818 1 Clinical Report Nasal Extranodal NK/T Cell Lymphoma with Orbital Involvement: A Rare Entity of Common Presentations Sharfudin Muhammad Hazim 1 Abu Bakar Muhammad Nasri 1 Abdul Manan Aifaa 1 http://orcid.org/0000-0003-4556-7601 Mohamad Umbaik Norsyamira Aida syamira@usm.my 2 Md Shukri Norasnieda 2 1 2 https://ror.org/02rgb2k63 grid.11875.3a 0000 0001 2294 3534 Department of Otorhinolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery, School of Medical Sciences, Universiti Sains Malaysia, 20 6 2024 10 2024 76 5 472259 4740 4743 6 5 2024 13 6 2024 01 10 2025 01 10 2025 07 10 2024 01 10 2025 © Association of Otolaryngologists of India 2024. Springer Nature or its licensor (e.g. a society or other partner) holds exclusive rights to this article under a publishing agreement with the author(s) or other rightsholder(s); author self-archiving of the accepted manuscript version of this article is solely governed by the terms of such publishing agreement and applicable law. 2024 Nasal Extranodal NK/T Cell Lymphoma is an aggressive tumour affecting the nasal and midline structures, causing surrounding tissue destruction as the result of its progression. The initial presentations are similar to symptoms of benign nasal polyps, such as nasal obstruction, hyposmia and nasal discharge. As the disease progresses, the involvement of the palate, paranasal sinuses, orbit and skin become alarming symptoms. We report a case of a young male with Nasal ENKTL who presented with symptoms similar to acute on chronic rhinosinusitis with orbital complications. The challenges of diagnosing and getting to the correct management pathway are discussed.
